title: based on false facts, twisted statements
review:
The documentary is based on false facts, which can be easily checked by a simple search.
It is interesting that the journalist, Richard Lapaitis, in an interview given to Azeri tv channel confesses that he is not historian (he is not familiar with he history of the region at all) and yet he confidently takes the right to cover historic events. The result is a documentary with no historic evidence but rather fragments of interviews taken out of context, translated into English and narrated by great actors, to serve as nicely packaged Azeri propaganda.
For example the documentary states that Nagorno Karabakh is a "unique Azerbaijani cultural island", whereas there is plethora of literature on indigenous Armenian people living on this land for centuries if not thousands of years. Further it sates that followers of the Albanian church used to peacefully coexist with muslims, which is another well-known and well-organized falsification of history by Azerbaijan which aims at erasing the presence of Armenians by twisted facts and has been criticized by many international scholars.
As for Khojali massacres, these are very tragic events, which unfortunately haven't been investigated. Azerbaijani president Ayaz Mutalibov when interviewed by independent Czech reporter Dana Mazalova, made the following statement: "What would you say about the Khojaly events, after which you resigned? At the time, corpses of people from Khojaly were discovered not far from Aghdam. Someone had shot them in the legs beforehand to prevent them from running away. Afterwards they were axed. On February 29th my colleagues filmed them. When we next filmed on March 2 these corpses had been scalped. What kind of strange game was that?". Mr. Lopaitis arrived in Aghdam after the massacre, he was moved by what he saw and heard and 20 years later decided to talk about it. This documentary would be more valuable if he could investigate and dig deeper into what really happened. He obviously couldn't do that and the eyewitnesses couldn't tell him anything that would be against their government. One journalist already tried (Chingiz Fuad-ogly Mustafayev) and was found dead a month later.
To keep this review short I won't cover the rest of the false statements. I would just say that the film may be very highly rated by Azeri population, but shouldn't be taken as serious source by those who want to learn more about the Nagorno Karabakh conflict, one of the most complicated in in the world.

Reporter Dana Mazalova who interviewed former president of Azerbaijan Ayaz Mutalibov and published the article in "Nezavisimaya Gazeta" reaffirms that irrespective of the efforts of the incumbent president of Azerbaijan Ilham Aliyev to distort the reality, her article is in full compliance with what former Azerbaijani president Ayaz Mutalibov said during the interview which took place in April, 1992.The reporter regrets that she was unable to preserve the recording due to technical reasons."There was no internet, there were no computers, but I reaffirm that what I wrote back then are what Ayaz Mutalibov said, I have not added anything. Now he can deny it as he wants, but he said it the way it is printed in "Nezavisimaya Gazeta" newspaper. I have the copy of that newspaper and its available on the net, Ayaz Mutalibov has said it", Dana Mazalova said in an exclusive interview with ARMENPRESS. Mutalibov gave an interview to Dana Mazalova after 1 month following his resignation.Mazalova heard about the tragic events of Khojaly from the video recordings of cameraman Chingiz Mustafayev, who had personally made exclusive records. "Chingiz, whom I met in Kislovodsk, told me in his apartment how those people were killed, they were hurting their knees so they couldn't go. The knees... the most vulnerable place on human's body. I was scheduled to take an interview from Ayaz Mutalibov the next day. I could not help asking him what I had seen in the records made by Chingiz. Of course, I did not say the name of my friend Chingiz not to harm him. After 2 months Chingiz was killed", the reporter recalls with grief.Dana Mazalova told also about another recording of Chingiz Mustafayev. The bodies of the victims of Khojaly events were seen in a video recording done on February 28 in front of the military positions of the "Popular Front" of Azerbaijani troops. According to Muslim traditions, the bodies should have been buried within two days, but Chingiz Mustafayev could record them also on March 2, but this time the bodies were taken to another place and were vandalized. In the video recording of February 28 it could be seen that Azerbaijani soldiers were walking near the bodies."I feel very guilty for not taking and copying those recordings. I feel so sorry up till now. I think you understand that my interview with Mutalibov was the result of those video recordings and my conversations with Chingiz", Mazalova said.To the remark of the reporter of ARMENPRESS that incumbent president of Azerbaijan Ilham Aliyev used the public platform of Munich Security Conference on February 15 to deny the words of Mutalibov, Mazalova emphasized, "I will put this way. We know that Turkey denies the Armenian Genocide up till now".One month after the Khojaly tragedy Azerbaijani president Ayaz Mutalibov was interviewed by Czech reporter Dana Mazalova.
What would you say about the Khojaly events, after which you resigned? At the time, bodies of people from Khojaly were discovered not far from Aghdam. Someone had shot them in the legs beforehand to prevent them from running away. Afterwards they were axed. On February 29th my colleagues filmed them. When we next filmed on March 2 these corpses had been scalped. What kind of strange game was that?As the rescued residents of Khojaly say, all that was organized to create grounds for my resignation. I don't think that the Armenians, who had manifested a clear and knowledgeable approach to such situations, would have allowed Azerbaijanis to obtain evidence that tied them to fascist acts. If I declare that it was the fault of the Azerbaijani opposition I could be blamed for slander. But the overall picture of the conclusions is as follows: the Armenians had, in any case, provided a corridor to let the civilians escape. Why then would they shoot? As soon as Khojaly was surrounded by tanks it was necessary to immediately lead the civilians out. Earlier I had given similar orders regarding Shushi - to evacuate women and children and to leave only men in the city. It's one of the laws of war - civilians must be rescued. My conduct was appropriate and unambiguous - I gave such orders, but why they weren't followed in Khojaly is not clear to me.

title: Khojaly . The real truth
review:
From the first days of the war against Karabakh, the cities of Shushi, Aghdam, Stepanakert, Khojaly, Malibeyli and other Azerbaijani settlements became the firing points of the capital of Artsakh and the nearby Armenian villages around the clock. The only airport connecting Artsakh with the outside world was located in the village of Khojaly, populated by Meskhetian Turks, which the Azeris had turned into the center of the Omani armed to the teeth. Russian journalist Angelika Chechina writes about those days. "I was in Stepanakert from January 21 to 25. There was no electricity or water in the city. Water was so difficult to obtain that you were ashamed to drink tea. It was impossible to sell food stamps, the shops were empty. There were already cases of starvation and death in the city. "Stepanakert was reminiscent of the blockade of Leningrad."
The destruction of the Khojaly firing points was undertaken by the Karabakh self-defense forces on February 26, 1992. According to independent observers and journalists, before the attack, Armenians, acting in accordance with the Geneva Conventions, used loudspeakers to urge residents to leave the city and get out of the encirclement through a humanitarian corridor along the Karkar River. According to the people of Khojaly, they used that corridor, and indeed the Armenian soldiers on the other side of the corridor did not open fire on them.
Azerbaijani journalist Eynulla Fatullayev writes about those days. ": Getting acquainted with the geographical location, I can say with all confidence that the allegations about the absence of the Armenian corridor are baseless. There really was a corridor, otherwise the people of Khojaly, completely surrounded and isolated from the outside world, would not be able to break through the circle and get out of the encirclement. However, on the other side of the Karkar River, a line of refugees was dispersed, and, for some reason, some of the Khojaly people were directed, or more precisely, directed by some people in the direction of Nakhichevanik. It seemed that the battalions of the People's Front of Azerbaijan were not seeking the liberation of the Khojaly people, but to shed more blood on the way to overthrow Mutalibov. : The strange and annoying thing is that under the torrential fire of the Armenians, our helicopters, which had difficulty reaching the entrances of Aghdam, were hastily transporting the animals and not the residents who were somehow rescued and arrived here. Who gave them such a terrifying task? Armenians...":
The author of the article was arrested and convicted on charges of "insulting Khojaly residents." New charges have been brought after the arrest, and in 2007 In late October, Fatullayev was sentenced to eight and a half years in prison. These testimonies were later officially considered "false" and "traitor".
Making Khojaly the subject of speculation, the Azeris, or more precisely, the Popular Front (led by Elchibey), and later father and son Aliyev, discredited and ousted incumbent President Ayaz Mutalibov in order to seize the coveted presidency, then in Baku, Sumgait, Kirovab, Azerbaijan. In order to counterbalance the genocide committed against the Armenian population in other settlements, false accusations were made against the Armenians, as if they had also carried out a massacre in the village of Khojaly.
In fact, the following happened. Analysis of foreign, Armenian and Azerbaijani independent sources, the words of the first president of Azerbaijan Ayaz Mutalibov shows that the representatives of the opposition People's Front in Aghdam deliberately misled the residents of Khojaly and the retreating military groups, directing them as Armenians liberated by Azeris instead of Aghdam. Clashing with the village self-defense forces and inflicting several dozen casualties, the panicked Azeris fled to Aghdam. It is near Aghdam that the mass murders of Azeris take place at the hands of their own people who have received a special assignment. This area is 3.5 kilometers away from Aghdam and 11 kilometers from Khojaly, until the end of July 1993 it was under the constant control of the Azerbaijani armed forces.
